docs.snippet: The Israel Film Board, a 10-member advisory board appointed by the Government, has selected ''Hamsin,'' a film critical of Israel as its nominee for the best foreign-language picture in Hollywood's Acaademy Awards competition. The choice comes at ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Israel Film Board, a 10-member advisory board appointed by the Government, has selected ''Hamsin,'' a film critical of Israel as its nominee for the best foreign-language picture in Hollywood's Acaademy Awards competition. The choice comes at a time when Israelis are increasingly sensitive to the way they are seen overseas. ''Hamsin'' takes examines relations between Jews and Arabs in Israel -relations that the film's director, Daniel Wachsmann, an Israeli Jew, portrays as a circle of fear, hatred and violence. The word ''hamsin'' means a hot Arabian wind that comes up from the desert. In the film, it is a metaphor for uncontrollable forces that sweep up all those in its path. In the movie, the hamsin is a wind of hate and fear that embroils both Jews and Arabs when the Government decides to take over Arab lands in a Galilee farming town. Although at first Jews and Arabs work well together, the land issue drives them apart, turning Arabs into terrorists and Jews into vigilantes and killers.

headline.main: OSCAR FILM IS CRITICAL OF ISRAEL

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: On the brink of her 100th birthday Monday, Estelle Winwood tipples Gallo cream sherry, plays bridge three times a week and smokes three packs of cigarettes a day.   Wearing metallic brown brocade and a huge triangular hat, gold bracelets on both a...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the brink of her 100th birthday Monday, Estelle Winwood tipples Gallo cream sherry, plays bridge three times a week and smokes three packs of cigarettes a day. Wearing metallic brown brocade and a huge triangular hat, gold bracelets on both arms and black patent-leather pumps, and looking like a cross between a medieval queen and a carving of an ancient Egyptian princess, the fey and deft character actress of more than 40 Broadway plays and a score of movies sits on her sofa at noon sipping her drink. Most noons she is still asleep in her four-poster bed. The habits of a lifetime in the theater are not easily broken. She eats breakfast at 12:30 P.M., reads in bed until 3 - she is currently halfway through Kenneth Tynan's ''Show People'' - and then begins telephoning for a bridge game or an escort to take her out to dinner, perhaps to Ma Maison, the trendy French bistro across the hills from her white stucco San Fernando Valley home. She goes out most nights. If she is forced to dine at home, she is likely to be so angry that she will smoke a pack of cigarettes in place of eating dinner.

byline.original: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: A small-scale army mutiny in northern Tanzania this month underlined that nation's economic malaise but apparently failed to dent President Julius K. Nyerere's grasp on the country.   Diplomats said the uprising involved officers from the Haya tri...
docs.lead_paragraph: A small-scale army mutiny in northern Tanzania this month underlined that nation's economic malaise but apparently failed to dent President Julius K. Nyerere's grasp on the country. Diplomats said the uprising involved officers from the Haya tribe, a relatively prosperous group from the Bukoba area on Tanzania's Lake Victoria border with Uganda in the north. The mutiny, directed against President Nyerere's leadership, was rapidly quashed by loyalists. One of those reportedly detained was Christopher Ngaiza, a former presidential aide who had been linked to a prominent Tanzanian dissident, Oscar Kambona, now in exile in London. The uprising was short-lived and confused, the diplomats said.

headline.main: FAILED MUTINY IS REPORTED IN TANZANIA

byline.original: By ALAN COWELL, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx, near the Mosholu Parkway exit of the Saw Mill River Parkway, has an array of performances scheduled this week through March that could help reduce the midwinter doldrums to a minimum....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx, near the Mosholu Parkway exit of the Saw Mill River Parkway, has an array of performances scheduled this week through March that could help reduce the midwinter doldrums to a minimum. The ''First Annual Jazz Festival'' opens with Oscar Peterson and the Stan Getz Quartet at 8 P.M. Friday in the concert hall. Chuck Wayne's Quartet and the Lehman College Jazz Combo are on from 4 to 6 P.M. Saturday in the theater, and Spyro Gyra and the Gary Burton Quartet take over at 8 P.M. in the concert hall. Billy Taylor and the Lehman College Stage Band perform from 1 to 3 P.M. next Sunday in the theater, and Benny Goodman and his Sextet, plus Bucky Pizzarelli and John Pizzarelli Jr., cap the festival at 3 P.M. next Sunday in the concert hall.

docs.snippet: ''THE DESPERATE HOURS'' is a psychological thriller that's superficial upon analysis and short on thrills. In the Theater Three production in Port Jefferson, which runs through Feb. 5, the director, George Carabin, appears to have emphasized yet a...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''THE DESPERATE HOURS'' is a psychological thriller that's superficial upon analysis and short on thrills. In the Theater Three production in Port Jefferson, which runs through Feb. 5, the director, George Carabin, appears to have emphasized yet another facet of Joseph Hayes's 1955 melodrama: the philosophizing, preachy part. The play, which is overwritten and underdeveloped, is, nonetheless, making a big statement about the contagion of violence and the ultimate triumph of humanity - and several smaller statements about justice, abiding by the rules, and the law. That's obvious enough - and Mr. Carabin dwells on it at the expense of theatricality.

docs.snippet: A movie doesn't have to be altogether clear to be immensely satisfying. Take, for example, Bertrand Tavernier's new French film, ''Coup de Torchon'' (translated by its distributors as ''Clean Slate''), which starts out as a conventional if exotic ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A movie doesn't have to be altogether clear to be immensely satisfying. Take, for example, Bertrand Tavernier's new French film, ''Coup de Torchon'' (translated by its distributors as ''Clean Slate''), which starts out as a conventional if exotic comedy, set in a small, parched town in French West Africa in 1938, and turns into a most provocative, wittily misanthropic melodrama set in the landscape of the soul. When we first see Lucien Cordier (Philippe Noiret), the mildmannered chief of police in Bourkassa, he seems to be a prototypical W.C. Fields character, but without Fields's saving grace of readily expressed fury at careless wives and slovenly in-laws. As Lucien moves around Bourkassa, he accepts the most outrageous insults from the other French colonials with nothing more than sheepish resignation. That which would produce rage in any other man prompts, in Lucien, an embarrassed shrug. A couple of seedy pimps pay him a bribe to overlook some minor infraction of the law and then, for laughs, dump him in the river with the bodies of black Africans who have died in a dysentery epidemic. When Lucien sees Rose (Isabelle Huppert), his pretty young mistress, being seriously beaten in the street by her husband, he cannot bring himself to help her. He assures a friend, without too much conviction, that it isn't because he's a coward but because the bystanders, knowing his relationship with Rose, would misunderstand his intervention.

headline.main: OBSCURITY AND COMEDY BLEND TO BUOY 'COUP DE TORCHON'

docs.snippet: Maybe Rudy May won't be leaving the Yankees after all.  May, the Yankee pitcher selected by the Chicago White Sox in the free-agent compensation draft on Thursday, became the center of a dispute yesterday when the Major League Baseball Players Ass...
docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe Rudy May won't be leaving the Yankees after all. May, the Yankee pitcher selected by the Chicago White Sox in the free-agent compensation draft on Thursday, became the center of a dispute yesterday when the Major League Baseball Players Association contended that he was improperly placed in the pool. Donald Fehr, the association's general counsel, said May had a notrade clause in his contract with the Yankees and that players with such clauses must be included on a team's list of players protected from the compensation pool.

headline.main: Players' Union Protests Selection of May

docs.snippet: BARNEY KESSEL has been playing jazz guitar in celebrated company for four decades - in Artie Shaw's Gramercy Five in the mid-1940's, with the Oscar Peterson Trio in the early 50's, on the star-studded Jazz at the Philharmonic tours of the 50's, as...
docs.lead_paragraph: BARNEY KESSEL has been playing jazz guitar in celebrated company for four decades - in Artie Shaw's Gramercy Five in the mid-1940's, with the Oscar Peterson Trio in the early 50's, on the star-studded Jazz at the Philharmonic tours of the 50's, as one of the top Los Angeles studio musicians in the 60's and, in the 70's, as one-third of the Great Guitars, with Charlie Byrd and Herb Ellis. He has been no stranger to New York during these years. But this weekend, for the first time in his long career, he is playing in New York as a headliner on his own. Accompanied by Steve Laspina on bass, he will be at Village West, Hudson Street, near Bank Street, through Sunday. This guitar and bass combination is more or less the way in which Mr. Kessel usually plays, aside from a few weeks each year with the Great Guitars and three or four weeks with Mr. Ellis.

headline.main: BARNEY KESSEL'S IN TOWN, A HEADLINER THIS TIME

docs.snippet: THE watchword of the week was flux. How could it be otherwise? The s cenery has lately been changing faster than you can say ''cocktail p arty,'' one of the best places to find out what the fashionable are d oing when they're not getting dressed. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE watchword of the week was flux. How could it be otherwise? The s cenery has lately been changing faster than you can say ''cocktail p arty,'' one of the best places to find out what the fashionable are d oing when they're not getting dressed. At a reception at the French Consulate last Wednesday where Pauline Trigere was reawarded the Vermeil Medal (the official ceremony had already taken place in Paris), Paloma Picasso was thinking about designer piracy. ''We're running into a little difficulty in Japan,'' she said as the room stared at her. ''Without my permission, someone has received a license to use my name, which is totally illegal. They'll pay for that.'' She smiled.
